quotes.t: There was a burst of applause, and a deep silence which was even more {qword}eloquent{/qword} than the applause.
Samuel Johnson is palmed off in classrooms as a harmless drudge of a lexicographer, yet open the Dictionary anywhere and find precision and {qword}eloquent{/qword} plainness.
He [H. L. Mencken] relished the vagaries of vernacular speech and paid {qword}eloquent{/qword} homage to them in {it}The American Language{/it}.

et: Middle English, borrowed from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French, borrowed from Latin {it}ēloquent-, ēloquens{/it} "capable of speech, expressing oneself fluently," from present participle of {it}ēloquī{/it} "to utter, put into words," from {it}ē-{/it} {et_link|e-:1|e-:1} + {it}loquī{/it} "to talk, speak," probably going back to dialectal Indo-European {it}*tlok{sup}w{/sup}-{/it} "talk," whence also Old Irish {it}ad-tluichethar{/it} "(s/he) gives thanks" (originally with {it}buide{/it} "thanks" as object, as in {it}atluchedar buidi do Día{/it} "he thanks God"), {it}do-tluichethar{/it} "(s/he) desires, beseeches, asks," Old Church Slavic {it}tlŭk{/it} "interpreter" (from {it}*tl̥k{sup}w{/sup}-o-{/it})
shortdef: marked by forceful and fluent expression
vividly or movingly expressive or revealing

dt.t: He {it}waxed eloquent{/it} on/about the pleasures of gardening.
